Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2013 03:42PM trail2 wrote: Hi Ladies,  I am reading your site for a friend that is having torso lymphedema problems and was interesting in your compression shirt discussion.  I have to wear compression garments for my work, and have tried several brands.  The ones that I find do the best job of compression and staying down I get at walmart in the men's department.  It is the Starter brand,  I then customize them with scissors  .  I don't like the high neck, so I cut off the neck section.  Even though it looks a little ragged, it has never continued to fray even with several washings.  I would think that you could get a long sleeve and cut the sleeve to the length that would comfortable adapt to your sleeve.  Sort of a 3/4 sleeve length.  Just thought I would make the suggestion.  This time of year you can often find the long sleeve shirts on sale for under 10 bucks, so you could try.  I get mine so tight that I sometimes have to have help pulling them down in the back, but once on, they stay in place. Hope this is helpful.  :)

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 03:28AM trail2 wrote: Hi fightn4fam,  I finished T/C back in June.  I didn't have itching, but did have tingling in my hand and feet.  It would come and go, and finally ended.  I just had surgery this week to get my nipple reconstruction, and had a terrible bout of itching that was caused by my pain meds.  Itching can be a sign of an allergic reaction, so keep an eye on it.  I saw where you tried antihistamines,  I took and still take Clariten every night.  My oncologist suggested it because it helped some people with the bone pain from the Neulasta shot.  I wish I could help more, but I hope it will stop soon.  As for your esophageal spasms,  My Dr prescribed the "miracle mouthwash"  it is good for sores in your mouth or in your throat.  I would swish then swallow, and it helped every time.  It has liquid benadryl, and lidocaine, and mylanta in it.  It helps with throat inflammation, numbs the part that hurts , and neutralizes the acids.   Good Luck, and hope you feel better soon.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 02:15AM trail2 wrote: Hi ,  You can add me to the March 2011 list.  I had a BMX with tissue expanders March 2nd.  My surgery went well.  Tonight is the first night I have tried to sleep in the bed.  I was very sore, and had trouble getting up and down or laying back, so I have been sleeping in the recliner.  I had the On Q pain pump, and my ps removed it today since it was empty.  It lasted about about 5 days.  I have two drains, and they are beginning to slow down, so maybe I can have them out soon.  I had a sentinel node injection, which the worst part was the numbing medicine, but I dont think I would have wanted to do it without numbing.  I had the pre op nurse take a picture of the markings the ps made for my breast surgeon.  I am so glad because I can look at the result and kind of figure out what they did.  I still am very sore, but mostly with movement.  I have a meeting with bs this thursday to hear about my plan of action.  Good luck to all who are next in line.
